section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Mark Curato
section-block.rac_book_summary: When Mouse goes to a family reunion, his friend Elliot misses him. Mouse knows just how to fix that!

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce the first letters of the children’s first names. Tell children that today we will learn about the first letters in our first names.
Recite “Families” with children: Some families are big. (spread arms out wide) / Some families are small. (bring arms close together) / But I love my family (hug self) best of all!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Little Elliot, Big Family, written and illustrated by Mike Curato.
Pablo loves to read stories about families. This story is about a pretend family, so this kind of story is called a narrative.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Who goes to Mouse’s family reunion?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This is our new book for the week. What information is on the cover? Follow along as I read aloud the title and author’s name. He wrote the words. He also made the all the pictures!
Mouse is excited. A family reunion is when a family gets together after being apart for a time. Why will a family reunion be fun for Mouse?
When Mouse leaves, the house is empty. How do you think Elliot feels to be alone in an empty house?
Wow! Elliot sees a lot of different families. What does he see?
What is the surprise that happens while Elliot is in the movie theater?
When we guess what will happen next in a story, we make a prediction. Let’s guess what might happen next! Where do you think Mouse will take Elliot? (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Who goes to Mouse’s family reunion?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, choose two or three children to share, using Equity Sticks.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about Mouse’s family, as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Mouse take Elliot to his family reunion?
Mouse takes Elliot to his f______ (family) reunion.
Mouse takes Elliot to his family reunion.
Why did Mouse invite Elliot to the reunion?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Reading to children from an early age is one of the best ways to help them develop the pre-literacy skills they need before they can read. As you read aloud a book’s title and the names of the creator(s), run your finger below each word. While reading a story, ask children to identify key words depicted in the illustrations.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Try to Resolve Conflict
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a discussion about the ways children can try to solve their own problems. Choose two children to act out this scenario. Two children both want to play with the hoop. They touch it at the same time. What should they do? Guide children to suggest they take turns. Continue with other scenarios.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about our Mind Builder as we revisit Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato. Let’s see what happens when Elliot waits for Mouse.
This story is about Mouse’s family. Clifford loves this book because it’s about special friends and family who work and play together.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do you think Elliot decides to go for a walk after Mouse left?
How can you tell from the picture how Elliot feels? Listen while I reread the words on this page. Then tell me how they help you know how he feels.
How do you know that the rest of Mouse’s family is also happy that Elliot has joined? (MB)
Elliot and Mouse’s family are having a great time! What are some activities they take turns doing? (MB)
Have you ever taken a picture with a lot of people? What do people use to take pictures? Let’s pretend to take a picture with cell phones. Get ready! Click!

section.rac_body-text: Remind children that sometimes if there is only one ball or toy, they have take turns with a friend. Let’s make two groups. One group will be the players, and one group will have to wait for their turn. The group that is waiting for their turn can count, or say the letters of the alphabet, or chat about all the fun they are going to have when it’s their turn. Ready?
Give the players small toys or blocks to play with. Have the waiting children sit. Set a timer for two minutes. Then have the groups switch roles. Give everyone two turns at each.
Talk about what it was like to be a player and what it was like to wait for a turn.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how Mouse’s family took turns at the family reunion.
Together, visit the author’s website to learn about other Little Elliot books.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that creative play is important in young children’s brain development. Though children are not aware of it, play is serious work for them! It provides opportunities to express and cope with emotions and supports cognitive growth as they explore new and unexpected ways of thinking and using materials.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that asking questions when we read helps make sure we understand a story. Who has a question about this week’s story?
Play “Follow Me” with children. Mime small actions family members may do; like put on glasses, read a book, or cook. Have children repeat your action.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Little Elliot, Big Family by Mark Curato.
Pablo loves how Elliot joins Mouse’s family in this narrative!
This is the guiding question I want you to think about.
Who does Elliot see on his walk?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Elliot takes a walk. What does he see?
When Elliot is walking in the park, who does he see?
Why do you think Elliot wonders what it would be like to have so many cousins? How do you know Elliot would like cousins, too?
Elliot sees something in the movie that makes him think of Mouse. What does Elliot see?
How do you know Elliot is having a wonderful time?
Mouse adds one more to his family. Who is it?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Who does Elliot see on his walk?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He sees a father with his daughters.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen as you work together to talk and write about what Elliot sees on his walk.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Elliot see cousins skating on his walk?
Elliot sees c_______ (cousins) skating on his walk.
Elliot sees cousins skating on his walk.
What are some things cousins might do together?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Playing games like Follow Me not only remind the children of the reading selection, but are a fun way to develop their perceptual motor skills. These skills help children figure out how their body is connected and how it moves.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about what children have learned about families this week. Are all families alike? How are some families different from others?
“Some have fathers,/Some have mothers,/Some have sisters,/Some have brothers./Some houses,/There are others./Every family’s special.”
Introduce new words to use children as they continue to talk about families.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read My Family and Me. It’s about many different kinds of families.
Pablo loves to read about different families and the things they like to do together.
Little Elliot, Big Family and My Family and Me talk about families. Listen for ways that they both show all kinds of families.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Little Elliot, Big Family cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how the concept question: What makes a family?
section.rac_body-text: Share the poster with children. Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart. Then, use these prompts to read and discuss the poster.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the mother reading to the brother and sister? When does your family read together?
Let’s count the family members in this photo. Touch your nose if you have a family pet.
Who can point to the father and two brothers? How can you tell they’re having a good time? What do you play with your family?
Wow! Look at all the family members in this picture. When do your family members get together for a special meal? What does this meal remind you of from Mouse’s family reunion?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Little Elliot, Big Family cover.

section.rac_body-text: Divide children into groups to represent a family. Then play charades, giving each “family” an opportunity to act out a family activity. Invite children to use different classroom objects and manipulatives as “props” as each family acts out their activity. Children in other groups can guess the activity.
Provide a writing prompt about families and what makes each one special. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When we point out cross-text connections to young children, we are teaching them to be more engaged readers/listeners. By guiding children to notice connections between texts, we are helping them realize a deeper understanding of both texts and recognize that the larger concepts have meaning in many different contexts.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that you and they are going to act out some of the things we like to do with family. Sing the following song to the tune of “The Muffin Man.” “Tell me what you like to do, like to do, like to do. Tell me what you like to do, with your family.” Invite children to share an activity they enjoy doing with their family. Have children act out the activity as they continue to sing along.
Introduce a new phrase that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato.
Pablo loves reading this narrative because even pretend families are fun to read about.
This week, we read about Elliot and Mouse, who learn that they are more than just friends. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What do we do with our families?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Elliot stretches when he wakes up. Then he and Mouse say good morning to each other. Can you show me how you wake up? What do you say to your family when you see them in the morning?
Elliot sees many families on his walk. Let’s pretend you see your family when we are on a walk. What are they doing?
In this story, family members play ball, read, sing, and skate. Which activity do you like to do with your family?
What do Elliot and Mouse say to each other when they are together again? Show me how you look when you miss someone.
Remember, a warm welcome is a friendly greeting. Turn to your neighbor and give them a warm welcome.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do we do with our families?
section.rac_body-text: Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about some one in their own families.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is Elliot part of Mouse’s family?
Elliot is part of Mouse’s f_____ (family).
Elliot is part of Mouse’s family.
How do you think Elliot feels at the end of the story?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It’s not unusual for children’s expressive language to lag behind their receptive language. They can understand more spoken language than they can use for expressing themselves. Multilanguage learners can benefit from the Day 5 story prompts, which invite children to act out parts of a story instead of asking for a verbal response.
